script:
3.6 percent.

Personal Savings Rate just dropped 30.8 percent in a single year. That's one of the most dramatic shifts we've seen in recent economic data. In this episode, we're going to break down exactly what's happening, what's driving it, and what it means for you. Let's follow the data.

Right now, personal savings rate stands at 3.6 percent. One year ago, it was at 5.2 percent. That's a 30.8 percent decline in twelve months. To understand why that matters, you have to see the full picture. This chart shows the complete history.

Watch how personal savings rate has moved over the past decade. You can see periods of stability... periods of gradual change... and then these sharp inflection points where everything accelerates. The move we're seeing now is one of those inflection points. The data is moving faster than at almost any point in the last ten years.

But personal savings rate doesn't exist in isolation. To understand the full story, we need to look at what's connected. Personal Consumption is currently at $21.5 trillion... that's up 4.7 percent year over year. Total Consumer Credit is currently at $5.1 trillion... that's up 3.1 percent year over year. Median Household Income is currently at $83,730.00... that's up 1.3 percent year over year.

When you put these numbers side by side, a clear picture emerges. These aren't random fluctuations. They're interconnected forces... each one reinforcing the others. And together, they tell a story that's more complex than any single headline.

Here's what this really means for everyday Americans. When the savings rate drops to 3.6 percent, it means the average household is saving just 3.6 percent of every dollar they earn after taxes. For a family earning $83,000 a year, that's roughly $250 a month going into savings. One car repair. One medical bill. One unexpected layoff... and there's no cushion. The last time the savings rate was this low for an extended period, it preceded the 2008 financial crisis. That doesn't mean a crash is coming tomorrow. But it does mean that the American consumer... the engine of 70 percent of GDP... is running on fumes.

That's the story behind personal savings rate right now. The data doesn't lie... and it often tells us things months before the headlines catch up. If you want to see more data-driven breakdowns like this, subscribe and turn on notifications. Every week, we track the numbers that actually shape the American economy. I'm The Money Map. See you in the next one.
